commit 67174775b88c6d48250b48f7385be4ecefb3071f
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Sun Oct 17 00:32:06 2021 +0200

    Added function `Picture::rotate_label_positions'.  It's called in
    
    `Scan_Parse::transformation_command_func' in `scanprsf.web', which, in turn,
    is called in the parser rule `command: ROTATE picture_variable numeric_list'
    in `ptrfcmnd.w'.
    
    `Picture::rotate_label_positions' only has an effect when a `Picture' is rotated around
    a single major axis by a multiple of +/-90 degrees.

 src/pictures.web | 273 ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++--

commit 3a1f930253f05284cfb9a960c0c77f33b32aa91d
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Sat Oct 16 18:57:42 2021 +0200

    Working on rotating labels on |Pictures|.  This works now.  However,
    
    I need to solve the problem of the label positions, i.e., "top", "bot", "lft",
    etc.  They are not automatically changed and there's no realistic way of doing
    this for rotations that aren't multiples of 45 around one axis.  However, I want
    to do this for the ones where it is possible.
    
    If all the labels on a picture are specified such that they lie directly
    on the point, rotation works.  Shifting the point can be used as an alternative
    to specifying a position.  This would make sense if the user knows that he or
    she will be rotating the picture.

commit 176cf89b590aacd042a4c9a0195223c809bc636e
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Sun Sep 12 21:31:58 2021 +0200

    Added code for writing the file `starinfo_constellations.tex'.  It's included in `clstsph1_a4.tex'.
    
    The other files with calls to the TeX macro `\starinfo' are created, directly or indirectly, by the
    a GNU 3DLDF macro in `astronmy.lmc'.  Unlike these files, `starinfo_constellations.tex' is generated by
    the program `accsdtbs' ("Access database tables").  This is a better method and I may use it for the
    other generated files, too.

commit d2510986ba8b68846c66c739c4971550e883b432
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Tue Aug 31 14:07:38 2021 +0200

    Finished tabs.  I was going to put a tab at the top and bottom of the spherical biangles,
    
    but I remembered that it would not be easy to do this, because the sides of the apparent triangles
    are really curves.  It would therefore take too much work to find points along them.  It would be
    much easier to use tape to connect the spherical biangles at the ends.

commit 049d646afa44b12e35d4a671dfc654a1e158ffe9
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Fri Aug 6 16:58:14 2021 +0200

    In `plot_star_on_spherical_biangle':  Added the arguments `boolean suppress_dot'
    
    and `boolean suppress_text_label'.  They can be used for stars that shouldn't be plotted
    for some reason, e.g., Polaris, which is at the top of the model where there is no room
    for a label.
    
    Since the macro is called, the point on the appropriate spherical biangle for the star
    is found (i.e., `R[x]') and most importantly, a call to `\starinfo' for it is written to
    `sample_5_star_info_combined.tex', so data for the star will appear in `sample5_a4.dvi',
    `sample5_a4.ps' and `sample5_a4.pdf', with a note that it's not plotted.

 src/astronmy.lmc | 97 +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++--------------------------
 1 file changed, 68 insertions(+), 29 deletions(-)

Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Wed Jul 7 02:35:10 2021 +0200

    This version works.  It _does not_ work to fill the spherical biangles with black
    
    and have the declination lines, the names of the plotted stars and the dots for the latter
    printed in white on top of them.  There seems to be some problem with the order in which
    the MetaPost commands in the MetaPost output file `sample3.mp' are executed.
    
    While testing, the results were puzzling.  Some things worked outside of loops but not inside them.
    Sometimes partial lines were visible.  Sometimes lines were covered up in the spherical biangles
    where a star was plotted but not in the others.  And so on.
    
    I will try a different approach to getting black spherical biangles with white dots and text.

Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Sat Jun 26 15:27:05 2021 +0200

    Restored parser rules for `star_expressions', `constellation_expressions' and `planet_expressions',
    
    as well as the corresponding "vector-types".
    
    `sphrmd02.ldf' and `sphrmd00.lmc' are now processed correctly.  Previously, `3dldf' blocked while trying
    to process them.  No changes were actually needed;  the problem was probably due to inconsistencies in
    the object files and the executable.

commit 74011c3b0ca6d6a5c7788df69fe52cb85d36ff72
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Fri Jun 25 20:42:19 2021 +0200

    Changed inline comparison functions to non-inline ones.
    
    I need to have pointers to these functions and I don't think it would
    be possible to have a pointer to an inline function.  g++ didn't issue
    an error, so maybe it is possible.  It could also be possible that the
    compiler doesn't inline the functions in this case, but it seems to me
    that it would be a fairly complex task to have the compiler do this.
    
    I think it's safer to just not declare them inline.

    upon start up.  It's possible to do this either by passing arguments to `3dldf' or

 doc/trnsfrms.texi | 135 +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

commit c9951331b4ae0d63d9a818e45bb1bde688c98e80
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Sun Apr 4 10:18:21 2021 +0200

    Removed calls to |cerr_mutex.lock()| and |cerr_mutex.unlock()|.
    
    Locking |cerr_mutex| caused the program to block in the rule for showing
    |point_vectors|.  Removing these calls elsewhere may cause problems when
    using multiple threads, if the mutex isn't locked elsewhere, e.g., in the
    calls to the various versions of |show|.  I may therefore have to recover
    them from the previous revision.

 src/pshowcmd.w | 103 +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++---------------------------------------------
 1 file changed, 50 insertions(+), 53 deletions(-)

commit 81f88c2a0e8e9060719fee3e7aacf266e3deef48
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Tue Mar 23 13:39:16 2021 +0100

    Removed superfluous blank lines.  Fixed some places where |cerr_mutex| was locked before
    
    a |show| function was called.  The |show| functions also try to lock the mutex, so the program
    blocked.  Many of these places are within debugging output.  I tried turning debugging on globally,
    but it produced so much output that I had to turn it off again.
    
    Many of these errors with |cerr_mutex| hadn't been discovered earlier because the debugging output
    in the relevant functions hadn't been turned on in a long time.

commit 6211707772fbe85bbb907dd6dba02df9d5c8b4c6
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Mon Mar 22 08:54:37 2021 +0100

    Now calling `compile_parser.sh' to conditionally compile `parser.c++'.
    
    If `parser.o' isn't up-to-date, `compile_parser.sh' queries the user whether
    to recompile `parser.c++' or not.
    
    Previously, `parser.c++' was often recompiled even though the code it contains hadn't changed since
    the last compilation.  This was a nuisance, because it takes a long time to compile `parser.c++'.

 src/Makefile.am | 28 ++++++++++++++++++++++++----
 1 file changed, 24 insertions(+), 4 deletions(-)

commit dfd4f437aecd700bf287da5fafcd8e8c2762338f
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gwdg.de>
Date:   Mon Nov 11 20:03:59 2013 +0100

    Merged in changes from `test_2013.11.10' branch:
    
       Removed code for parser "locations".  The Bison code was outdated and apparently incompatible
       with newer versions of Bison.  Since I hardly used locations anyway, I have just removed or
       commented-out the relevant code.  I may replace it if and when I get around to revising the
       parser.
    
       Now passing |static_cast<Point*>(0)| as final argument to all calls to the version |Path::set| using
       variable arguments that I could find.  I think I found them all, but it's difficult to be sure without
       changing the declaration and trying to recompile to catch the errors.
    
       Variable arguments are also used in a version of the |Path| constructor, but I don't think this
       function is called anywhere.
    
       Comparing plain 0 with |static_cast<Point*>(0)| no longer worked with GCC 4.8.2.
    
       Changed the type of `real' (defined using `typedef') from `double' to `float'.
       I don't think double precision is needed.  Choosing which type to use is hard-coded.
       I plan to make it possible to decide this by using an option to the `configure' script,
       but not until a future release (after finishing the current bug fixes).

 src/3DLDFcpl.web  |  2 +-

Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gwdg.de>

    In |Dodecahedron::get_tabs|:
    
       BUG FIX:  Now casting final argument of |Path::set| to |Point *|.

       but caused a run-time error when it was changed to |float|.

commit d7a6342793cd7b69ca89e449e9441b07372025ac
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gwdg.de>
Date:   Sun Nov 10 16:29:21 2013 +0100

    In |Pointer_Vector<C, C>* convert(Pointer_Vector<D, D>*& d)|:
    
       BUG FIX:  Now explicitly resizing |c->v| with |static_cast<C*>(0)|
       as the value.  Previously, |operator+=| was called to push the pointers onto
       |c->v|.  Now, the existing NULL values are replaced.
    
       I don't think this should be necessary:  The older code worked with GCC 4.6.2,
       but it caused a compilation error with GCC 4.8.2:  Apparently, |vector::resize|
       was called with |Shape| instead of |Shape *| as the value type, which didn't work,
       because |Shape| is an abstract class.
    
       In addition, I've had to change the type of derivation of |Path| from |Shape| from
       |protected| to |public|.

 src/pntrvctr.web | 21 ++++++++++++++++++++-
 1 file changed, 20 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

commit ccb00264920e9cf5c0c30ee8b1e47a728ae5038d
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gwdg.de>
Date:   Sun Nov 10 16:17:37 2013 +0100

    In @<Define |class Path|@>:
    
       BUG FIX:  Changed the type of derivation from |Shape|
       from |protected| to |public|.  This caused a compilation error in
       |Pointer_Vector<C, D>::convert| when compiling with GCC 4.8.2.
       It had still worked with GCC 4.6.2.

commit cafe108f21a6554b79c80a6d03d7e8d99e0b6356
Author: Laurence Finston <lfinsto@gwdg.de>
Date:   Sun Aug 11 20:50:51 2013 +0200

    No longer using "timer" files.  Changed the extension of the generated header files from `h' to `h++'.
    Actually, `.h' files are generated by `ctangle' and they are renamed to `h++' if the code has changed
    or if no `h++' already exists.  Changed the "include" commands in the CWEB files appropriately.

commit a93e884384d4e54c9e2a8d6394004dfac1231705
Author: Laurence Finston <lfinsto@gwdg.de>
Date:   Sun Aug 11 20:50:19 2013 +0200

    Initial version in this directory.

 CWEB/check_scan_parse_output.sh | 29 +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
 1 file changed, 29 insertions(+)

commit 4e1b637bb3ed1dbc4889202be90204fdef4610b3
Author: Laurence Finston <lfinsto@gwdg.de>
Date:   Sun Aug 11 20:49:41 2013 +0200

    This version works.  Changed code so that a library is built and `3dldf' is linked against it.
    Now "touching" target files to prevent repeated compilation, etc.  This is necessary because
    of the use of `ctangle':  Sometimes, the target files end up being older than the prerequisites
    unless the former are "touched".  This occurs when the prerequisites are newer, but the changes
    don't affect the compiled code.  The situation is more complicated with the Bison and Flex
    input files.
    
    No longer using "timer" files.  Changed the extension of the generated header files from `h' to `h++'.
    Actually, `.h' files are generated by `ctangle' and they are renamed to `h++' if the code has changed
    or if no `h++' already exists.  Changed the "include" commands in the CWEB files appropriately.

 CWEB/Makefile.am | 162 ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++--------------
 1 file changed, 137 insertions(+), 25 deletions(-)

commit 2dbde568c8ecbff31ead51dd92ef00493456c821

commit c267f9e882d550d5ef63e71aa3148ad935650981
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Sun Jul 21 19:18:22 2013 +0200

    Working on getting rid of calls to the template function `create_new'.  Replacing them
    with calls to plain `new'.  `create_new' doesn't do anything that's needed.  I originally
    planned to use it to keep track of what objects were created, but I never had any need to do
    this I don't think the overhead is justified.

 src/Makefile.am | 76 ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++------------------------------

commit b63508b79d99b2e5d76971493e3354827035cd6f
Author: Laurence Finston <Laurence.Finston@gmx.de>
Date:   Mon Jun 3 20:50:47 2013 +0200

    Commented-out 'AC_PROG_CC'.  I was having problems
    with 'libtool' using 'gcc' to compile the (generated) source files for
    the Flex scanner 'scanner2' and the Bison parsers.
    I don't think I need to use 'gcc' as a C compiler for anything.
    If necessary, I can compile any C programs using 'g++'.
    If I ever really want to compile something without the overhead of a
    C++ compiler, I can change the way the generated files are handled.
    That is, I can rename the '.c' files generated by 'ctangle' so
    'make' doesn't get confused and think they're C sources.
